key_title: Key to the species of Erica

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Ericaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Ericaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Ericaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Corolla more or less campanulate, up to 10 mm long; stamens included in corolla
Corolla tubular, more than 20 mm long; stamens usually slightly exserted
Corolla white to pale pink, urceolate to campanulate, not or hardly 4-angled; sepals less than half as long as the corolla
Corolla magenta-pink, globose, 4-angled; sepals subequal to corolla
Young stems with simple hairs only; flowers often pinkish
Young stems invested with shortly branched hairs; flowers white or cream
Corolla distinctly narrowed toward mouth (i.e. broadest above level of separation of lobes); lower bracteole of 3 inserted some distance below the upper pair
Corolla not or hardly narrowed toward mouth (lobes arising at about the widest point); lower bracteole of 3 inserted immediately below upper pair, the 3 appearing ± whorled
Rounded shrubs, often divaricately branched; angle between corolla lobes acute
Plants erect; angle between corolla lobes conspicuously rounded
Plants covered in long gland-tipped hairs, leaves usually in whorls of 4; flowers pink or white with red longitudinal ridges
Plants with short eglandular hairs, mostly restricted to stems; leaves in whorls of 3; flowers red, sometimes greenish or yellow at tips
Bracteoles c. 6 mm long, subtending sepals; sepals more than 7 mm long; petals tubular or trumpet-shaped, red with greenish or yellow tips; anther filaments attached at towards base of anthers
Bracteoles c. 1 mm long, near base of pedicle; sepals less than 4 mm long; petals tubular, tube and lobes red; anthers with high dorsal attachment
